citations.narrative:
The licensee has gone over the allowed animal maximum on their USDA license. Present at the facility at the time of
inspection were a total of 210 animals and their license authorizes for 100. Additionally, two fennec foxes, two bat eared
foxes, and two servals were among the animals present and are not shown as authorized on the license.
The USDA license authorizes an animal number maximum for your facility. It also specifically authorizes the use of each
of the following groups of animals: Group 5 and Group 6 nonhuman primates, exotic and wild felids (ie., lions, tigers,
leopards, cheetahs, jaguars, cougars, lynx, servals, bobcats, and caracals); exotic and wild canids (ie., wolves, coyotes,
foxes, and jackals); and mega-herbivores (ie., elephants, rhinoceroses, hippopotamuses, and giraffes). This information
helps ensure that all animals can be adequately housed and cared for at your facility.
A licensee must obtain a new license before any change resulting in more than the authorized number of animals on hand
at any single point in time during the period of licensure. A new license must also be obtained before using any animal
beyond those types or numbers of animals authorized under the existing license.
Correct by 10/25/25.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.1(b)(2) 
   
Requirements and application 
The licensee has gone over the allowed animal maximum on their USDA license. Present at the facility at the time of 
inspection were a total of 210 animals and their license authorizes for 100. Additionally, two fennec foxes, two bat eared 
foxes, and two servals were among the animals present and are not shown as authorized on the license. 
 
The USDA license authorizes an animal number maximum for your facility. It also specifically authorizes the use of each 
of the following groups of animals: Group 5 and Group 6 nonhuman primates, exotic and wild felids (ie., lions, tigers, 
leopards, cheetahs, jaguars, cougars, lynx, servals, bobcats, and caracals); exotic and wild canids (ie., wolves, coyotes, 
foxes, and jackals); and mega-herbivores (ie., elephants, rhinoceroses, hippopotamuses, and giraffes). This information 
helps ensure that all animals can be adequately housed and cared for at your facility.  
 
A licensee must obtain a new license before any change resulting in more than the authorized number of animals on hand 
at any single point in time during the period of licensure. A new license must also be obtained before using any animal 
beyond those types or numbers of animals authorized under the existing license. 
 
Correct by 10/25/25. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
